newsitem.title: USA: US House panel okays higher international flight fee.
newsitem.headline: US House panel okays higher international flight fee.

text.p: The House Ways and Means Committee early on Friday approved a plan that would replace a proposed tax on Indian tribal businesses including gaming with an increase in an airline fee on international flights.

The committee, in a vote that crossed party lines, voted 22-16 to approve an amendment that would raise international departure and arrival fees to $15.50 per passenger from the $10 fee proposed in the committee chairman's bill. The fee is currently $6.
The vote came as the committee continued working on a broad tax bill to cut federal taxes by a net $85 billion over five years.
Some committee members, who opposed taxing Indian tribal commerce, said they were equally opposed to raising air travel fees and struggled with the decision.
The full tax bill, if approved by the committee, would then go to the House floor for a vote.

Committee chairman Bill Archer, a Texas Republican, who had proposed the Indian gaming tax in his bill, said casinos on Indian reservations brought in revenues of $4.5 billion in 1995. "They have a clear tax advantage, which is a major advantage to them," Archer said.
Archer's bill called for the international fee to be indexed using the Consumer Price Index beginning Jan. 1, 1999.
On Monday, Archer said U.S. international flight fees were among the lowest in the world and his plan would move to correct that.
